awd_titl_txt: Gravitational Radiation from the Milky Way -- Searching for Continuous Waves from Spinning Neutron Stars
awd_abstract_narration:
The recent discoveries of gravitational waves from colliding black holes and from colliding neutron stars marked key milestones in science, simultaneously confirming fundamental predictions of Einstein's General Relativity, while opening up an entirely new field of astronomy. The detection of continuous gravitational waves from rotating galactic neutron stars will mark another major milestone because such sources are expected to continue emitting for long durations, allowing follow-up investigation of increasing precision,
including correlation with potential signals in the radio, optical, X-ray and gamma-ray bands. Combining these gravitational and electromagnetic signals will provide critical insight into the poorly known structure of these exotic stars. The research to be carried out, on both the instrumental and analytical sides, will provide training to undergraduate and graduate students in state-of-the-art science at the frontier of knowledge.

Research will focus on a number of specific areas related to the Advanced Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (Advanced LIGO) Experiment: 1) searches for continuous gravitational waves using methods developed originally by the Michigan group; 2) pioneering new search methods that probe more deeply and computationally more efficiently potential sources of continuous gravitational waves in binary stellar systems; and 3) detector characterization of Advanced LIGO interferometers focused on spectral
line identification and mitigation, in order to improve searches for nearly monochromatic continuous gravitational waves.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Discoveries

Gravitational waves now provide a new window to the universe, thanks to the exquisitely sensitive interferometers of LIGO (Laser Interferometer Gravitational Wave Observatory). Following the discoveries of gravitational waves from binary black holer mergers (2015) and from a binary neutron star merger (2017), the LIGO-Virgo Collaboration has carried out a third observing run (2019-2020) in which many dozens of additional mergers were detected, including neutron star --- black hole mergers. These additional detections have greatly improved our understanding of compact star evolution and dynamics. As charter members of the LIGO Scientific Collaboration (LSC), the Michigan Gravitational Wave Group has taken on leadership and major responsibilites within the LSC, in the quest to discover gravitational waves and with them to observe new phenomena in the universe. The PI co-led the Continuous Waves search group for nine years, served on the LSC Executive Committee and Management Team, served on the Detection Committee, which validated the GW150914 discovery before its announcement to the world in early 2016, and now co-leads the LSC Editorial Board.


Intellectual Merit

The Michigan group's primary focus in the LSC is to find continuous gravitational waves radiated by rotating neutron stars in the galaxy. The PI co-led the LSC working group searching for such  continuous-wave sources for nine years, with effort devoted in recent years to preparing for discovery in the Advanced LIGO era, which began in fall 2015. Published searches have been carried out by the Michigan group in the O1+O2+O3 data sets for both isolated and binary neutron stars in our galaxy. Event deeper searches are now under way by the Michigan group in the O3 data for continuous waves from isolated neutron stars in the galaxy. The Michigan group also carried out the first search for dark photon dark matter in gravitational wave strain data and contributed to LSC follow-up searches.

During the Advanced LIGO era, the Michigan group also worked extensively in detector characterization focused on identifying and mitigating spectral artifacts that can degrade searches for continuous waves. Data from Advanced LIGO commissioning, from engineering runs and from the first observing run have been carefully scanned and spectral artifacts reported to commissioners. 

Broader Impacts

Over the years the Michigan group has trained many graduate students, many undergraduates and a handful of high school students to work at the forefront of physics research and instrumentation. The group has taken full advantage of several special programs at the national and university level to attract students, including female and Hispanic students.

The PI and graduate students have given outreach talks, including several video-taped "Saturday Morning Physics" lectures which are shown regularly on local Ann Arbor community television.

The group has also collaborated with the Ann Arbor Hands-On Museum (for which Riles served for two terms on the Board of Trustees) in building LIGO-related exhibits.
